fields.description:
h3. Summary

Failing attempts to log in to JIRA, and also failing attempts to log into id.atlassian.com directly such that both trigger the account lockout can cause a second lock on the account that cannot be removed automatically.

h3. Environment
N/a

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Using the REST API, attempt to log in against JIRA with a bad password enough such that known good passwords fail due to lockout.
# Using the REST API, attempt to log in against id.atlassian.com with a known bad password such that known good passwords fail
# log in with the Captcha to clear the lock

h3. Expected Results

The user becomes unlocked and REST API calls are able to log in again.

h3. Actual Results
User is still locked out and unable to use REST API requests still.
 
h3. Notes
N/a

h3.Workaround
no known workaround at this time
fields.summary: Failed attempts to log in to JIRA, and Identity prevents user from being able to remove lockout.

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition
At the moment, exporting user information from User Management will use comma as the default delimiter and it is not possible to change the delimiter prior exporting.

h2. Suggested Solution
Provide the ability to choose the delimiter prior exporting the user information (e.g: comma, semicolon, tab)
fields.summary: Provide an option to choose the CSV delimiter for user export

fields.description:
h3. Summary

G Suite does not sync, error: We're syncing existing users as usual, but there is a problem with the default groups for some of the products so we stopped syncing in new users. To start syncing again, configure your application access and we'll fix the problem with the next sync.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Create an user with some upper case letters on the email (ie: User@support.com)
Have the same user existing on the G Suite group with the email in lower case letters (ie: user@support.com)
Have users on the G Suite group that does not exist on the instance
Perform a GSync

h3. Expected Results

G Suite syncs successfully and new users are created.

h3. Actual Results

It throws an error pointing to the application access configuration as the problem.
fields.summary: G Suite does not sync - We're syncing existing users as usual, but there is a problem with the default groups for some of the products so we stopped syncing in new users.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When self sign up is enabled and a user signs up, the site admin receives an email address with the link user-management-west.atlassian.io instead of the Cloud instance URL.

Template:
{quote}
User (user@domain.com) has just joined user-management-west.atlassian.io. Check out User's profile.
{quote}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Enable self sign up in the site administration of your Cloud instance.
# Have a user sign up on your Cloud instance.

h3. Expected Results
The email received by the site administrator displays the link to the Cloud URL.

h3. Actual Results
The email received by the site administrator displays the following link instead: {{user-management-west.atlassian.io}}

h3. Notes
The user can still access the instance.

h3.Workaround
None
fields.summary: The email received when a user signs up on a Cloud instance displays the wrong link

fields.description: Administrators should have the ability to specify a single email address or group other than Administrators that receive the self signup email request asking for access.
fields.summary: Ability to control self signup email recipients.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Some instances are occassionally getting connection problems while talking to id.internal.atlassian.io. This seems to be either connection or requests timeouts.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Send a lot of REST requests to a Cloud instance using basic authentication (so that each request will need to be authenticated against the Identity platform)


h3. Expected Results
You get correct responses for each request

h3. Actual Results
Some of the requests fail because "id.internal.atlassian.io:443 failed to respond". 
Below is the 'meaningful' part of the exception returned:
{noformat}
Caused by: org.apache.http.NoHttpResponseException: id.internal.atlassian.io:443 failed to respond
at org.apache.http.impl.conn.DefaultHttpResponseParser.parseHead(DefaultHttpResponseParser.java:141) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.conn.DefaultHttpResponseParser.parseHead(DefaultHttpResponseParser.java:56) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.io.AbstractMessageParser.parse(AbstractMessageParser.java:261) [httpcore-4.4.4.jar:4.4.4]
at org.apache.http.impl.DefaultBHttpClientConnection.receiveResponseHeader(DefaultBHttpClientConnection.java:165) [httpcore-4.4.4.jar:4.4.4]
at org.apache.http.impl.conn.CPoolProxy.receiveResponseHeader(CPoolProxy.java:165) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.protocol.HttpRequestExecutor.doReceiveResponse(HttpRequestExecutor.java:272) [httpcore-4.4.4.jar:4.4.4]
at org.apache.http.protocol.HttpRequestExecutor.execute(HttpRequestExecutor.java:124) [httpcore-4.4.4.jar:4.4.4]
at org.apache.http.impl.execchain.MainClientExec.execute(MainClientExec.java:272) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.execchain.ProtocolExec.execute(ProtocolExec.java:185) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.execchain.RetryExec.execute(RetryExec.java:89) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.execchain.ServiceUnavailableRetryExec.execute(ServiceUnavailableRetryExec.java:85) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.execchain.RedirectExec.execute(RedirectExec.java:111) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.client.InternalHttpClient.doExecute(InternalHttpClient.java:185) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.client.CloseableHttpClient.execute(CloseableHttpClient.java:83) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.client.CloseableHttpClient.execute(CloseableHttpClient.java:108) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at org.apache.http.impl.client.CloseableHttpClient.execute(CloseableHttpClient.java:56) [httpclient-4.5.3.jar:4.5.3]
at com.atlassian.idp.client.IdentityPlatformClientImpl.executeVerifyAppCredentialsRequest(IdentityPlatformClientImpl.java:190) [idp-client-1.176.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.idp.client.IdentityPlatformClientImpl.verifyAppCredentials(IdentityPlatformClientImpl.java:185) [idp-client-1.176.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.IdentityPlatformRemoteDirectory.authenticateViaEmailWithHostname(IdentityPlatformRemoteDirectory.java:209) [crowd-remote-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.authenticateWithHostname(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:255) [crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.authenticateUserWithHostname(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:283) [crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.lambda$authenticateUserWithHostname$2(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:194) [crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.authenticateUserImpl(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:222) [crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.authenticateUserWithHostname(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:194) [crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.lambda$authenticateWithHostname$1(CrowdServiceImpl.java:84) [embedded-crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.authenticateImpl(CrowdServiceImpl.java:107) [embedded-crowd-core-1000.103.0.jar:?]
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
The issue is just temporary. Usually waiting couple of minutes and re-sending the request works fine.


h3.Workaround
Use Cookie authentication. This way you create the session once and then you use the information stored in the cookie to authenticate all the successive calls. So, unless you get the exception when creating the session, you will never face the issue for the successive requests.

For details and instructions:
- [Cookie-based auth for REST APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/jira-rest-api-cookie-based-authentication/]
- [JIRA REST API Example: Cookie based Authentication|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Example+-+Cookie-based+Authentication]

Another option is to use Oauth (more secure but requires some more effort to be implemented):
- [OAuth for REST APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/jira-rest-api-oauth-authentication/]
- [JIRA REST API Example: OAuth authentication|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Example+-+OAuth+authentication]
fields.summary: Occasional troubles connecting to the Identity Platform

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Users are able to Self-Sign Up on Instances with Self-Sign Up Deactivated

h3. Description
Administrators are receiving notifications for new users requesting access on instances with Self-Sign Up deactivated.
It also seems to be affecting instances with "Any account with one of the following email address domains can sign up" - Instead of filtering requests from that domain only, it lets anyone from any domain to sign up.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# On an instance, disable the "Self Sign Up""
# Access the instance from another account - which doesn't have access to that instance

h3. Expected Results

You should get a message stating that you don't have access to that site.

h3. Actual Results

You see the button "Request Access" and by clicking on it, all administrators get a message stating that you've requested access.

 !image-2017-07-13-11-55-36-508.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Users are able to Self-Sign Up on Instances with Self-Sign Up Deactivated

fields.description:
The new 'private profile' feature is causing problems in our corporate environment.

Our employees, if they select 'private' for their profile are practically un-findable by other employees in our company.

However, if they select public, it's my understanding that Atlassian is publishing their personal info (name, avatar, email) on the web via id.atlassian.com.

Instead, we need a way to have profile info be controlled and visible within the company but still locked down outside of the company. These are corporate accounts tied to a corporate email; users shouldn't have to worry about it being exposed outside of the company.

 

Please clarify what info is public (shared) and private (never exposed).

 

...feel free to restate this product-request.

 

Thank you.
fields.summary: instances should have internal-display-name and public-display-name

fields.description:
h3. Summary
JIRA or Confluence import fails when the instance has an annual license and the backup contains more users than the license seats.

h3. Environment
* 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start a Cloud instance with an annual license for 10 users.
# Export JIRA from another instance where 15 users have access
# Import fails as there aren't enough seats

h3. Expected Results
Import finishes and the user chooses who will have access once the instance is accessible

h3. Actual Results
Import fails and the application is locked
{noformat}
Unable to create the user as you have insufficient license seats for JIRA 
or
Unable to create the user as you have insufficient license seats for Confluence 
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* 

h3.Workaround
* Revoke groups' access on the source instance
** Keep only the permissions for administrators
* Create the backup
* Grant access to the groups once again
* Import the backup on the target instance
fields.summary: Import fails due to an insufficient amount of license seats

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Before the implementation of Atlassian Account, users could create users with a non-valid email address for BOT accounts. After the Atlassian Account enabled, the BOT accounts are having issue as per [Atlassian account - Upgrade impact|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/the-upgrade-to-atlassian-account-873871204.html#TheupgradetoAtlassianaccount-Upgradeimpact].

Since AA user can no longer create bot accounts in cloud instances. Sites that already had bot accounts are still able to continue with their old bot account but no new accounts with unverified emails can be created. Outside of that the only way to gain API access for a third party app or internal script is by using users' username and passwords which is a security concern. 
h3. Suggested Solution

The best alternative to this would be for users to be able to manage API tokens that can be used with our APIs. 

h3. Why this is important
 * Users have many scripts run heavily for daily tasks, all these scripts are facing issues after the implementation Atlassian Account
fields.summary: Alternative to using user credentials for API access

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Before the implementation of Atlassian Account, users can create Cloud users with a non-valid email address for BOT accounts. After the Atlassian Account enabled, the BOT accounts are having issue as per [Atlassian account - Upgrade impact|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/the-upgrade-to-atlassian-account-873871204.html#TheupgradetoAtlassianaccount-Upgradeimpact].

Also, the scripts with BOT accounts are failed due to this bug: ID-6351 - REST API calls are returning '401 Unauthorized' after Atlassian Account is enabled in the instance.

The suggested workaround is not applicable for BOT accounts as we don't have a valid email address in creating an Atlassian Account.
h3. Suggested Solution
 - Allow signing up for an Atlassian Account without verifying the email address
 - Allow in-app password (within Cloud, not tie to Atlassian Account) so admin can update the password from Cloud.
 - Ability to mark user as BOT, so admin can change the password and no Atlassian Account required

h3. Why this is important
 - Users have many scripts run heavily for daily tasks, all these scripts are facing issues after the implementation Atlassian Account
 - Users sometimes create test accounts before launching their projects/space/instance
fields.summary: Allow Bot Accounts On Cloud Instances

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of 31 Jan 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#4C9AFF|bgColor=#DEEBFF}
Hi everyone,

Bulk import of users and groups from an external system is supported via the new User provisioning (SCIM) API. We're pleased to announce that documentation for the [API is now available on developer.atlassian.com|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/admin/user-provisioning/rest/]. The API is an implementation of the [SCIM specification|http://www.simplecloud.info/] and is intended to be used to sync users and groups from an identity provider to an [Atlassian organization|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/set-up-an-atlassian-organization-938859734.html]. Once you have linked an Atlassian Cloud site (like example.atlassian.net) to your organization, users and groups will be synced to your site and you can use them to control access to Jira and Confluence Cloud as well as permissions within those products. [Learn more about how automatic user provisioning works with Atlassian Cloud|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/user-provisioning-959305316.html].

There are several key benefits to automating user provisioning for Atlassian Cloud:
 * It saves you time as an administrator by automating the process of creating and removing Atlassian accounts for your users
 * It improves security by reducing errors in the provisioning/deprovisioning process
 * It can help reduce costs by ensuring you are not billed for users who are no longer active

The SCIM API is intended for customers who are not already using one of our supported identity providers. [We currently support *Okta*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/configure-user-provisioning-with-okta-957492956.html] and are actively working on support for *Azure Active Directory* and *Onelogin*. If you are using one of these identity providers, we recommend using the supported Atlassian app for these identity providers as this will simplify the configuration process.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
Atlassian Access Product Management
{panel}

h3. Problem Definition

With the new Identity Platform for Cloud instances, it is not possible to bulk import users.

h3. Suggested Solution

Create a Bulk User import Tool for either Atlassian Support or for end user to import a list of users via CSV
h3. Why this is important
 * This is a problem when migrating from JIRA Server to JIRA Cloud. External Directories are not support in JIRA Cloud. Users will need to be added manually
 * Helpful feature for customers that wish to import all existing users into a new Cloud instance
 * Key problem when attempting to merge two sets of users from Cloud instances (Cloud-to-Cloud merger)

h3. Workaround

No workaround
fields.summary: Create tool for Bulk Importing Users into Cloud

fields.description:
As a part of our attempt to reduce the number of domain claims that are missing their domain claim token we are checking the token periodically and sending a warning email after the first failed re-verification.

Some customers are getting multiple emails every time their token is intermittently unavailable (due to network errors and such). When the customer checks their domain claim status is VERIFIED as we've re-checked some time later and the intermittent failure has been resolved.

We should reduce this customer impact by only sending out the warning email if the verification fails multiple checks in a row.
fields.summary: Only send domain claim re-verification emails after multiple failed verification

fields.description:
*Problem Description*

Currently, JIRA does not allow the administrator to track the users who have changed the password and provide the list on the period of time taken to change the password or the days before the password will expire for a certain user.


*Scenario:*

    The administrator wants to check on how many users have changed the password before the expiry date fixed
    The administrator wants to check how many days are left before the password has expired for a user

*Challenge:*

    To improve security by keeping track on how fast a user responds to the password reset dateline trigger. 
 
*Suggested Resolution:*

    Have an option to filter the users by date on when the password was last changed and how long will the password set be valid until the next password reset.
fields.summary: Ability to filter the users by date on when the password was last changed

fields.description: When the domain in the instance is verified, the users receive an email informing about this. It would be useful if the admin could opt to send this email or not. Or, could opt to send just to the administrator users of the instance. For example, Two instances could divide the same domain. When the domain in verified in the instance, all users in the domain will receive the email. One user, outside of the Atlassian instance, but inside of the domain, might receive an email and do not know the why.
fields.summary: Domain verification email

fields.description:
h3. Summary

On instances where SAML SSO is configured, updates to a user's email address breaks the ability for that user to log into the instance. This error is thrown, and access is not granted:

"Error reported: Your email address for 'old.email.address@example.com' has changed to 'new.email.address@example' at your Identity Provider. Ask your administrator to make the corresponding change on your Atlassian products."

Other error:

"Error reported: The authenticated email address we were expecting was 'new.email.address@example.com', but we received 'old.email.address@example.com'. Please ensure they match exactly, including case sensitivity. Contact your administrator to change your email to match."

Updating the email address in the User Management console as instructed doesn't resolve the issue. The same error message is thrown when attempting to log in.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Update email address on SAML admin panel
 # Try to login, error is thrown - see "Actual Results"
 # Update the email address on User Managment console on instance
 # Try to login, error is thrown - see "Actual Results"

h3. Expected Results
 * Access to instance is granted

h3. Actual Results
 * An error message is thrown:
{quote}"Error reported: Your email address for 'old.email.address@example.com' has changed to 'new.email.address@example' at your Identity Provider. Ask your administrator to make the corresponding change on your Atlassian products."
{quote}

h3. Notes
 * Seems to affect instances configured to use SAML for SSO

h3. Workaround
 * Contact support and quote this bug ticket(ID-6365) for assistance
fields.summary: Single Sign-On(SSO) via SAML: User is unable to log in following an email address change/update

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In the User Management when creating a new user, customer is unable to create an email address with an " ' " (apostrophe character), For example, [test'jira@atlassian.com|mailto:test'jira@atlassian.com]

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a user with an apostrophe character in the email address column.

h3. Expected Results

The creation of the email address with the apostrophe character is supposed to be successful.
h3. Actual Results

An error is thrown out when the user is attempted to be created. 

!Create User Error.png|width=386,height=343!

 
h3. Workaround
 # Create the user email address without the apostrophe character. 
 # After the creation, go to User Management > Search for the user > Click on the user name > Click on Edit > Change the email address and key in the apostrophe character where it's necessary  > Click Save
 # The user will receive an email notification and will be able to verify the creation.
fields.summary: Email containing apostrophe character cannot be created

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Cloud Customers who have configured SAML for authentication in their Cloud Instances are sent to the id.atlassian.com login page and prompted for an Email Address before being sent to the IdP provider which requires the user to re-enter their email address

Customers who only have their Company/Domain access their Cloud Instance would prefer the Login Experience to pass the user directly through to the configured IdP rather than having to verify on id.atlassian.com

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide an option where Admins can configure login to be passed through directly to their configured IdP
fields.summary: Passthrough Cloud Login to IdP Instead of id.atlassian.com

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

Once users set up SAML on their instance, there is no way to set a timeout session after certain time of inactivity and it would be great to have it.

h3. Suggested Resolution
Provide a feature to set user timeout session after certain time of inactivity
fields.summary: Provide a feature to set user timeout session after certain time of inactivity

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When there are less than 5 users in the User Management, the Bulk Create button is hidden.
h3. Suggested Solution
Allow Bulk Create even when there is only a small number of user in User Management.
h3. Why this is important
This will allow admins to initiate user creations much faster.
fields.summary: Allow Bulk Create users

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Administrators cannot manage the details of their users on their domain, that are not on their instance.
h3. Suggested Solution

Allow the ability to manage Atlassian accounts across JIRA / Confluence Cloud instances.
h3. Why this is important

The purpose of managed domains is to allow administrators to manage users accounts. 
 As of now, administrators can only manage accounts in the JIRA / Confluence Cloud instance where they have claimed the domain.

There can be instances where a single company uses multiple JIRA / Confluence Cloud instances to segregate data across various departments / teams.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no workaround. However if you plan on using more than one JIRA / Confluence Cloud instance, please claim the domain in which you have more users.
fields.summary: Ability to allow an administrator to manage the details of their users on their domain on a second JIRA/Confluence instance

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In the event of customers being prevented from logging in through SAML due to a case mismatch between their email addresses on their Identity Provider and their instances, they may be required to update the cases of their email addresses in the User Management.

For instance, customer has email address *abc.def@domain.com* in their IdP and *Abc.Def@domain.com* in their instance; hence, they need to update it in the UM. However, nothing happens when they update it from upper cased to lower cased (or vice-versa) because UM ignores cases. 

To workaround it, they first need to update it to something else like *Abc.Def+1@domain.com* (which will create a new Atlassian Account), and then to *abc.def@domain.com* (which will make the old Atlassian Account to become unverified). 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Verify domain
# Update email from *Abc.Def@domain.com* to *abc.def@domain.com*
fields.summary: User Management should be case sensitive

fields.description: The email received by the customer contains a link to "reset password" which is too big. Some email handlers might understand that as spam and the user never get the correct email. It will be useful if this link is simplified or conducts the customer directly to the page to reset the password, so, a simple link to the page.
fields.summary: Simplification reset password email

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Have password field ready to allow support for password management to automatically fill both email address and password. 
!image-2017-06-12-13-09-03-952.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
# Enter email address and the password field will appear.
# Have password management to fill the password.
fields.summary: Have password field visible to allow support for password management eg. 1Password

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

A company has an instance CloudA with their domain verified, they also have another instance CloudB, which has different users under the same email domain. Admins are only able to managed users in CloudA, and not able to modify users in CloudB eventhoug they already claimed domain in CloudA (they are not able to verify domain twice)

h3. Suggested Solution

- Create a feature to allow the safe ownership verification of the same domain in multiple instances, this way accounts on both instance can be managed in the instance itself. 

h3. Why this is important

- As we move forward to provide a suite of awesome applications for bug tracking, knowledge and development, we must understand that big companies may have more than one Cloud instance, it is important that they are allowed to managed their users in all those instances.
 
h3. Workaround 
When you want to manage users in CloudB
# Unverified the domain in CloudA
# Verify the domain in CloudB
# If you want to do manage users in CloudA again, repeat the same process
fields.summary: Improve Domain Verification To Cover "Managed Accounts" in Multiple Instances

fields.description:
h3. Summary

After Atlassian Accounts is enabled the REST API calls are failing returning {{401 Unauthorized}} if Google apps or SSO are used to log-into the instance.

In the response header you can see:
{noformat}
X-Seraph-LoginReason: AUTHENTICATED_FAILED
{noformat}
According to [JIRA REST API Example Cookie based Authentication|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Example+-+Cookie-based+Authentication]:
{quote}When you get an error response from JIRA, you can check for the presence of an *X-Seraph-LoginReason* header in the response, which will contain more information. A value of *AUTHENTICATION_DENIED* or *AUTHENTICATED_FAILED* means the application rejected the login without even checking the password, which most commonly indicates that JIRA's CAPTCHA feature has been triggered.
{quote}
However, since Google Apps or SSO are used to log-into the instance, the user is never prompted the captcha and therefore the failed passwords attempts counter is never reset.
h3. Environment

JIRA v1000.1043.1
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have a JIRA instance already configured to use Google for authentication.
 # Enable Atlassian Accounts and verify the email.
 # Try to authenticate REST API calls using the credentials that always worked

h3. Expected Results

The correct response or a meaningful error message is returned
h3. Actual Results

You get 401 unauthorized. The response header looks like:
{noformat}
HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
Server: nginx
Date: Thu, 08 Jun 2017 13:53:40 GMT
Content-Type: text/html;charset=UTF-8
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Connection: keep-alive
X-AREQUESTID: **********
X-Seraph-LoginReason: AUTHENTICATED_FAILED
{noformat}
In the logs the below exception can be found:
{noformat}
ERROR [atlassian.usermanagement.aid.AtlassianIdServiceImpl] Error verifying credentials for user@host.com
....
java.lang.RuntimeException: AidErrorEntity{errorMessages=[{"errorMessages":["Reached number of invalid password attempts for user user@host.com"],"errors":{},"errorCodes":{},"globalErrorCodes":["REACHED_NUMBER_OF_INVALID_PASSWORD_ATTEMPTS"]}], errors={}}
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

A) Reset the password for the user in [id.atlassian.com|https://id.atlassian.com/] by going to:
 - [https://id.atlassian.com/manage/change-password]

If this is not applicable because you didn't have a password previously set in [id.atlassian.com|https://id.atlassian.com/] and therefore you cannot use the change-password form. Then do the following:
 # Go to [https://id.atlassian.com/login/resetpassword]
 # Enter you email, complete the CAPTCHA and click on *Send*
 # Once you receive the password reset email, do not click on the button to Access but on the link below that says "reset password".
 # Fill up the new password and you are done.

B) Use [Cookie-based Authentication|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/jiracloud/JIRA+REST+API+-+Cookie-based+Authentication].
 # If you're on Chrome, you can install an extension called [*cookies.txt*|https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/cookiestxt/njabckikapfpffapmjgojcnbfjonfjfg?hl=en]
 # Then, log into your instance and click on the extension
 # Copy the cookie information (the data shown in the extension) and save it to a text file
 # Use the cookie stored in the text file to authenticate REST API calls by using the *-b* argument in Curl.
Example:
{code:java}
curl -b path/of/file/cookie.txt -H "Content-Type: application/json"  -X GET https://example.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/issue/TEST-1
{code}
fields.summary: REST API calls are returning '401 Unauthorized' after Atlassian Account is enabled in the instance

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* Issue where customers on verified domains are unable to reset passwords.  When a JIRA admin tries to reset a user's password via User Management, User Management acknowledges the action, the user's password is invalidated - but there is no email activity.
* Resetting from https://id.atlassian.com/login/resetpassword works.
* Removing verification restores the admin's ability to reset passwords.

h3. Environment
* JIRA v1000.1043.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* Ensure that the JIRA account you're trying to reset is on a verified domain.
* In User Management, click "Reset password".
* A message appears indicating that the process was successful and looks like a password reset email was triggered.  The message reads like "Done! We've invalidated User1@example.com's password. They will have to reset their password before they can log in again."
* Email is never received(mail logs indicate that an email was never sent).

h3. Expected Results
* Password reset email is delivered to end user's mailbox.

h3. Actual Results
* No email activity on mail logs.
* End user does not receive the password reset email.
 
h3. Notes
* Removing domain verification will restore this functionality.

h3.Workaround
* While on Private Browsing or Incognito tab, navigate to https://id.atlassian.com/login/resetpassword and generate a password reset email from there.
fields.summary: When triggered via User Management, password reset emails are not being sent to email addresses on a verified domain

fields.description:
h3. Summary

User who are given access to Confluence only (while there are JIRA in the instance), will be redirected to JIRA Dashboard/Customer Portal (if the instance has JIRA Service Desk) when they try to access the instance's URL
h3. Environment

JIRA v1000.1010.1
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a user and give Confluence access only (in default environment, include the user in "confluence-users" group only)
 # login as the user
 # Try to access the instance's URL (<instance-name>.atlassian.net)

h3. Expected Results

User redirected to Confluence (<instance-name>.atlassian.net/wiki/discover/all-updates)
h3. Actual Results

* User may receive a "Too Many Redirects" Error
* OR, they are redirected to JIRA (<instance-name>.atlassian.net/secure/Dashboard.jspa) as a logged out user (can see log in button on top right) 
* OR, they're logged into the JIRA Service Management Customer Portal

h3. Notes

This happened simultaneously with the appearance of this bug:
 - Unable to choose default homepage anymore in Atlassian Cloud

h3. Workaround
* Have an admin set their home product to Confluence - [https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/set-your-site-homepage-873871363.html]
* Navigate to <instance-name>.atlassian.net/wiki and the user will be re-directed to Confluence
* Navigate to start.atlassian.com to land in the Atlassian Product Portal  

----
{panel:title=Original Description}
In some states, user sites will stop redirecting users to the correct product based on their permissions. In particular, this means that users with access to Confluence but not JIRA will end up at the JIRA dashboard or the JIRA Service Desk anonymous user portal page instead of the Confluence dashboard.
{panel}
fields.summary: Some users with access to only Confluence are not being redirected to Confluence

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Due to some infrastructure changes around Cloud applications, instances that are running under some specific circumstances can present issues where new users are created with their profiles set to Private, but it's not possible to change it to Public, where their full names are shown as in the user's Atlassian Account at https://id.atlassian.com.

For clarification, due to security concerns, the local user account is marked as censored when the user's display name at the site does not match their display name at Atlassian account. In this case,  in place of an Atlassian account's Full name, their local username will be displayed.

When that's the case, the user even sees that his/her profile is censored while looking at the profile page but clicking the link *Change your privacy setting* takes the user back to JIRA's dashboard (see screenshot below). 

Another way to change the privacy of your profile would be by logging out from the applications as well as from https://id.atlassian.com and log back in. The user should then be prompted to choose how the profile should be shown.

h3. Workaround
None at the moment.

h3. Environment
Cloud - JIRA v1000.1034.2

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new user

h3. Expected Results
Two scenarios:
# User details should be pulled from the corresponding Atlassian Account correctly.
# In the event of having profiles set to private, users should be able to change it accordingly.

h3. Actual Results
Profiles are set to private and the user can't change it.
fields.summary: Users being created with their profiles set to Private and it's not possible to change it

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Up until recently there used to be a link within a user details in the User Management to resend the invitation email to this user, however this link is now gone.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have a Cloud instance in the IdPlat
# Create a test user
# Click its name to see its details

h3. Expected Results
The "_Resend_" would be right below the User Statistics
h3. Actual Results
The link isn't there.

h3.Notes
See screenshot for example.
!Screen Shot 2017-06-05 at 15.24.11.png|thumbnail!

h3.Workaround
Click the "_Reset password_" button will send an email to the user for it to set its password.
fields.summary: Link to resend user invitation is gone

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Can't login to Atlassian Cloud instance either through Safari or Chrome

h3. Environment
* Tested in iOS 10.3.1
* Tested in Google Chrome Mobile Version 56.0.2924.79

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to https://<CLOUD_INSTANCE>.atlassian.net
# Get redirected to https://id.atlassian.com
# Enter credentials

h3. Expected Results
Redirected back to https://<CLOUD_INSTANCE>.atlassian.net as a logged in user

h3. Actual Results
Got Redirected to https://<CLOUD_INSTANCE>.atlassian.net/login?dest-url=%2Fplugins%2Fservlet%2Fmobile%23myjirahome and got the the following screen:
*  !WhatsApp Image 2017-06-04 at 4.45.05 PM.jpeg|thumbnail!  

h3.Workaround
None at the moment
fields.summary: Can't Login to JIRA Through Mobile Web Browser (iOS)

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Users are unable to remove the avatar from {{id.atlassian.com}}.

h3. Step to Reproduce

# Login to {{id.atlassian.com}}.
# Go to https://id.atlassian.com/profile/profile.action
# Click on (x) on top left corner of the avatar

h3. Actual Result

Nothing happens and avatar doesn't get removed.

h3. Expected Result

Avatar is removed.
fields.summary: Unable to remove avatar from id.atlassian.com

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

From time to time, admin would need to check the request made, IP address, date and time for certain user. At this moment, this is not available in JIRA/Confluence Cloud.

h3. Suggested Resolution 

Provide logs to check user IP address and the request made to the instance.
fields.summary: Provide logs to check user IP address and request

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

A company has an instance CloudA with their domain verified and SAML enabled, they also have another instance CloudB, without SAML, which is used by the same users under the same email domain, when users try to login to CloudB, they get redirected to CloudA, not being able to access the instance by the normal login process, only through passwordless login.

h3. Suggested Solution

- Create a feature to allow the safe ownership verification of the same domain in multiple instances, this way the SAML can be setup on them as well.

h3. Why this is important

- As we move forward to provide a suite of awesome applications for bug tracking, knowledge and development, we must understand that big companies may have more than one Cloud instance, it is important that they are allowed to use a SSO solution to access all of their products even on multiple Cloud instances.
 
h3. Workaround 

# Click on "Having trouble logging in?"
# Input your email address from your account on the instance
# Use the passwordless login link provided on the email
fields.summary: Improve domain verification to extend the SAML functionality to cover multiple instances

fields.description:
h3. Summary
License usage section under the application access screen is not showing the correct number of avaialbe licenses (available seats). 


h3. Environment
* Tested in cloud


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to Application Access screen (under user management section)
# Check "License Usage"

h3. Expected Results

The number of available licenses to match the user subscription (i.e: for 100 users subscription) should show a maximum of 100 users

h3. Actual Results
It is showing a maximum of 2000 users, regardless of what subscription it has.
 
h3.Workaround
Check license under Billing section and compare to the number of licenses used.
fields.summary: License Usage shows wrong user limit (available seats)

fields.description:
At the moment, if an account is set as private in Atlassian Cloud User Management's panel, the user will have to change it themselves in https://<instance-name>.atlassian.net/login 

As an admin for the verified domain who is able to manage the user's Full Name and email address, I would also like to be able to set the user to be private or not.
fields.summary: Allow Admin of Verified Domain to Set User's Profile as Private or Not

fields.description: Syncing a members of a group that is only a small subset of a large userbase in G Suite still requires the current process to run over the entire userbase in order to fetch user details. Finding a way to speed up the synching time in those case would be great.
fields.summary: Improve group sync performance for large userbases

fields.description:
After the upgrade to Atlassian Account, administrators are not able to edit the full name/display name of the user locally in the instance. It will adopt the full name of the user from https://id.atlassian.com

However, there will be time where we would like for the name to appear differently in different instance. This would especially be the case if a user will have an account in another instance as a "Client" or a "3rd Party" with my company name as label in order to differentiate myself from others.
fields.summary: Enable site-admins of a Cloud Instance to set the display name of a user in the instance

fields.description: For some customers, being able to log back into the applications simply by entering the URL without having to log in again might be consider a security flaw. Having the option to remove cookies when the browser is closed in normal browser mode would be sufficient.
fields.summary: Add an option to remove cookies when browser is closed

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Adding a user with an invalid email address does not show any validation error. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
- Go to user management
- Add a user with an invalid email address {{test@test,com}}

h3. Expected Results
- Form validation should indicate an error message

h3. Actual Results
- No error message indicated in the browser. Upon inspection of the network traffic, the actual POST request to add the user with the invalid email address failed with 500 response code.
fields.summary: Adding a user with an invalid email address does not show any validation error

fields.description:
With the rollout of Atlassian account with domain verification The "Reset password" button in the Atlassian Cloud site admin console invalidates a user's password **immediately** with no confirmation prompt. This is a problem when the button is clicked **accidentally** such as when one intended to click a neighboring button, and there is no way to recover – the user must then reset her/his password. 

 

Desired Solution:

 

*Please add a confirmation prompt*
fields.summary: As an Admin I'd like the "Reset Password" button for individual users, to provide a prompt before resetting.

fields.description: With the move to Atlassian Account, users are not able to have 2 accounts sharing the same email in their JIRA/Confluence instance. It'd be a great if there's a public facing page to let the users know about it.
fields.summary: Would be a good idea to create a page explaining that an email can only be used once in a Cloud instance

fields.description:
h2. Summary

Currently, when bulk creating users with Bulk User Creation, and use an incomplete email format. The error message is misleading as it displays a wrong message stating, *"User creation is currently unavailable. Please try again later or contact your administrator.*

 

  !image-2017-05-18-16-09-23-901.png|thumbnail!
h3. Steps to Replicate
 # Navigate to instance.atlassian.net/admin/users/invite
 # Enter an invalid email
 # The error message is not correct.

h2. Expected Result

It should state that the email is invalid.
h2. Current Result

It is stating that *User Creation is Currently Unavailable*.
fields.summary: Incorrect Error Message when using Bulk User Creation

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Currently, when users try to login to Cloud Instance. Some users encounter *"Too many redirections during login" and "Your operation is taking longer than usual".* 
h3. Steps to Replicate
 # Try to login
 # Get  *"Too many redirections during login" and "Your operation is taking longer than usual".*  error.

h3. Expected Result

Login successfully.
h3. Current Result

Login return with *"Too many redirections during login" and "Your operation is taking longer than usual".*  error.

h3. Workaround
Please [raise a support ticket|https://www.atlassian.com/company/contact] in order to apply the fix.
fields.summary: Errors during login

fields.description:
Allow integration between identity providers and Atlassian Cloud which exists on Atlassian Data Center:  SAML single sign-on for Atlassian Data Center applications-
Supported Identity Providers - https://confluence.atlassian.com/enterprise/saml-single-sign-on-for-atlassian-data-center-applications-857050705.html#SAMLsinglesign-onforAtlassianDataCenterapplications-SupportedIdentityProviders
fields.summary: Allow SAML on a generic device that implements the SAML protocol

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
From customer(Context: redirection from instance to a different domain - [id.atlassian.com|https://id.atlassian.com]):
{quote}
User agents are not required to send the Referer header and it is generally considered unreliable for doing anything important. The W3C and RFC specs typify its use as being for non-functional concerns. I think the dependency on a refer header in your implementation should be reconsidered...
{quote}

h3. Suggested Solution
* Implement other ways to broker authentication.

h3. Why this is important
* Redirection to another domain can fail due to security/privacy implementation that customers have.
 
h3. Workaround 
* None.
fields.summary: Change redirection action to id.atlassian.com for authentication

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After enabling G Suite, the Gravatar avatars get lost.

h3. Environment

* Jira Core.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Enable G Suite.

h3. Expected Results
All Avatars from Gravatar should work fine.

h3. Actual Results
Avatars went missing and display the custom blank avatar.

h3.Workaround
None.
fields.summary: Enabling G Suite mess up avatars from Gravatar

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If a group is deleted and then recreated without an interval of at least one minute, the database will not synchronize the group's name. This happens when trying to recreate a group to change the name's case (e.g. from {{JIRA-Users}} to {{jira-users}})

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group.
# Recreate it with the same name but changing between uppercase and lowercase.
# Check the database and you will see the name of the group as it was before the recreation.

h3. Expected Results
The group name should be updated on the database. This inflicts custom fields and other functions to show the wrong name of a group.

h3. Actual Results
The change in the name's case is not reflected on the database, and custom fields will still show the group's name prior to the update.

Entry on the user management UI:
!group.png|thumbnail! 

Entry on the group picker custom field:
 !picker.png|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround
# Delete the group
# Wait one minute
# Recreate the group
fields.summary: Group name not updated after being recreated

fields.description:
h2. Summary
When converting _Portal-only customers_ to Atlassian Account, the respective Atlassian Account user will be automatically granted the application access to all applications.

It is stated in this [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/select-the-right-account-for-your-jira-service-desk-customers-873871210.html] that converting Portal-only customer to Atlassian Account will not consume the application license.

h2. Steps to reproduce
# Go to User Management
# Go to Portal-only customer section
# select one of the customer
# click _Convert to Atlassian account_

h2. Actual behavior
The Portal-only customer will be converted to Atlassian Account with application access

h2. Expected behavior
The Portal-only customer will be converted to Atlassian Account without application access to the applications
fields.summary: Converting Portal-only customer to Atlassian Account grants application access to all applications

fields.description:
h2. Summary

Before Atlassian Account, users of JIRA on instances that did not have Gravatar enabled and who did not have an avatar set had an initial from their name displayed on issues they were assigned to on a scrum or kanban board. When Atlassian Account is enabled on an instance, the initials will be replaced with a a generic image.
h2. Environment
 * Atlassian Account enabled JIRA Software Cloud instances.

h2. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a JIRA Software instance.
 # Disable Gravatar
 # Assign a user who has no avatar to an issue on a board.
 # Opt the instance into Atlassian Account

h2. Expected Results

The assignee's initial is visible on issues they are assigned to.
h2. Actual Results

A generic default avatar image is displayed instead of the initial.
h2. Workaround

Users can upload an avatar to their Atlassian Account to be displayed on issues they are assigned to.
fields.summary: Initialed avatars missing for users without avatar on instances with SSO enabled

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The customer can't stay logged in in multiple instances with different users if Atlassian Account is enabled and the option to add the customer as admin in both instances isn't suitable for the user.

h3. Suggestion
* Allow to log into mutiple accounts on id.atlasssian.com like Google, so we can stay logged in on different instances.
* Allow different login cookies for different instances so we can stay logged in on different instances.

h3. Why this is important
Sometimes, we work on multiple instances. For security reasons, we are required to use different email addresses for each instance. So, we have to keep logging in and out to work on different instances is not convenience at all.
 
h3. Workaround 
Use an incognito window for other users.
fields.summary: Ability to stay logged into multiple accounts and Cloud instances with Atlassian Account

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Customer's with SAML implemented into their Cloud instance cannot log in through SAML in Capture for JIRA, they need to use their Atlassian Account email/password combination for login.

h3. Workaround

It's required to users to reset their Atlassian Account password and use this to log in when using Capture.
fields.summary: Extend SAML authentication to Capture for JIRA

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
By design, scenarios where a user's "Full name" on their Atlassian account and "Full name" on the corresponding JIRA account does not match, the end user can choose whether to "show" or "hide" their details.  JIRA admins are unable to influence this behavior.

h3. Suggested Solution
* Implement a way for JIRA admins to have some level of control over this feature.
* Streamline the process and present fewer steps to the JIRA admin and end user.

h3. Why this is important
* More overhead for the JIRA admin as they will need to advise users of this extra step.
* Limit confusion for end users.
 
h3. Workaround 
Ask the end user to select "Let others see my full name" when logging into an instance for the first time, or update the setting from the "Change your privacy setting." link on the user's profile in JIRA.
fields.summary: Provide more control for JIRA admins regarding end user profile privacy/censorship feature

fields.description: When the customer connects or disconnecting from Saml, it sends an email to the organization informing the change. Would be useful if this email is sent only to the administrator or certain users, instead to send to all organization.
fields.summary: SAML integration disable domain verification email

fields.description:
h3. Scenario

Currently, when creating a new user using G Suite sync these users created this way don't receive any notice that they were invited to an instance JIRA or Confluence, it would be better if they received an email inviting them to use the application.

h3. Suggestion 

Unfortunately, our documentation says we are going to invite those users, we need to update that as well, to improve the user experience a welcome email should be sent inviting new users to start working on the applications.

{quote}
Users who are new to your Atlassian site—We'll provision and invite these users, giving them default application access the first time the sync runs. As a result, you can start mentioning them in comments or issues even before they start using the product.{quote}

- https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/g-suite-faqs-873871245.html
fields.summary: Consider sending a Welcome invite email for users created using Google Suite

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The user expects to see Homepage selection, but instead, it shows the message "This feature is temporarily unavailable. Please check back soon.".
h3. Environment
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to https://<instance>/admin/apps.
 # On the right panel, click on *User Defaults*

h3. Expected Results

Each user has their last session displayed correctly.
 !image-2017-05-08-16-16-12-136.png|thumbnail!
h3. Actual Results

No selection are available, shows the message "This feature is temporarily unavailable. Please check back soon." instead
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround

No workaround at the moment
fields.summary: Unable to configure Homepage

fields.description:
h2. Summary

Site-admins are not getting notification when Self Sign Up is enabled, and when it is set to restrict by domain. It is supposed to *send an email to site administrators when a new user signs up*. 
h2. Steps to Replicate
 # Turn on self sign up
 # Restrict it to a domain
 # When a user sign up, no notification is being sent out.

h2. Expected Result

It should *send an email to site administrators when a new user signs up*
h2. Current Result

It is not *sending an email to site administrators when a new user signs up*
h2.
fields.summary: Site-admins are not getting notification when Self Sign Up is enabled.

fields.description:
In [Set Password Requirements|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Cloud/Set+password+requirements], it doesn't mention in details about the password policy strength. For example numeric and non-numeric, number of special characters, repeating characters, etc.

It would be great if this information is updated to reflect Atlassian Account password strength.
fields.summary: Add more details about password strength

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Some users on IdPlat unable to logout
h3. How to replicate
 # User logged into id.atlassian.com.
 # Go to their Instance
 # Logout from the instance.

h3. Actual Result
Users are still logged in

h3. Expected Result
They will be able to log out

h3. Workaround
# Go to https://id.atlassian.com
# Login
# Go into the instance https://<instance>.atlassian.net
# Click on the Logout from the instance (JIRA/Confluence)
fields.summary: Users unable to log out for IdPlat instance

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Export Users button is disabled in User Management

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Click on the cog icon !https://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/157679812/Cog.png! on the right top menu and select User Management
# Try to export users through the Export Users button

h3. Expected Results
The button is available and functioning properly

h3. Actual Results
The button is disabled and it's not possible to export the users.
fields.summary: Export Users button is disabled in User Management

fields.description:
As an admin, I'd like the ability to add a label to my site users to help my site users distinguish between users they're unfamiliar with.

This is mainly to clarify a user's relationship with my site - for example "Display Name - Client 1", or "Display Name 2 - Staff" where Display Name is the Atlassian account display name, and Client 1 / Staff are the labels I apply at my site (these wouldn't appear anywhere else). 

This label should appear in all @mention locations, any profiles, etc. within the site, to avoid confusion about which John Smith you're talking to.
fields.summary: Allow a Site Admin to label users within their site

fields.description:
h3.Summary
With the move to Atlassian Account, users will need to relogin again after they have restarted their browsers (no keep me logged in option). This occurs on Cloud instances, and you can check out some of the examples in the comment section below.

h3.Steps to reproduce
# Login to a Cloud instance (that has Atlassian Account enabled)
# Close the browser
# Open the browser again, and navigate to the Cloud instance again

h3.Expected Behaviour
We are automatically logged in again

h3.Observed Behaviour
We are required to log in again.
fields.summary: Need to login again after restarting browser (Atlassian Account)

fields.description:
h3. Summary
According to ID-6217 ; users are required to logout and login to their instance again after changing their Full Name in [Atlassian Account|https://id.atlassian.com/manage] for the change to take place. However, even after logging out and in again, it still doesn't work.

The reason for this is a privacy feature with Atlassian Account. When somebody is being migrated to Atlassian Account and their full name is different to the name on the site we don't synchronise it just in case this would expose unintended details to the site administrators.

The user interface which would allow users to uncensor your name on your own is not available for all customers yet, but support staff are able to manually uncensor user accounts.

h3. Environment
* Atlassian Cloud using Atlassian Account


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to id.atlassian.com
# Change Full Name and save
# Log out of Atlassian Cloud instance and log back in

h3. Expected Results
* Full Name/Display Name is updated to reflect the one in Atlassian Account

h3. Actual Results
* Full Name/Display Name didn't get updated
 
h3.Workaround
The censored user may file a support case and we are able to manually change the names on the site to match the Atlassian Account. As this is an individual privacy feature the request must come from the user, not the site-admin.
fields.summary: Full Name in Cloud instance doesn't synchronize with Atlassian Account

fields.description:
h3. Summary

On-going incident preventing successful login to Cloud products with Atlassian account enabled.  Including [support.atlassian.com|https://support.atlassian.com].  
StatusPage: [Current Status|http://status.atlassian.com/incidents/kz9n65qlcljd]

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Attempt to log in using Atlassian account(Atlassian ID)

h3. Expected Results
* Successful login

h3. Actual Results
* Error: !ErrorLogin.JPG|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround
* No current workaround
fields.summary: Not possible to login using Atlassian account

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The Google ID of a user is associated with the incorrect Atlassian ID(AID).  Customers may have multiple AIDs because of an email address change(or similar).  Login process fails as described in "Actual Results" below.  Users are unintentionally forced to authenticate with the incorrect AID as a result of the Google ID being associated with the incorrect AID.

h3. Environment
* JIRA 1000.910.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Google Apps(G-Suite) for single sign-on
# Try to log into instance using the correct email address and password

h3. Expected Results
* Successful login and access to JIRA/Confluence

h3. Actual Results
* User is presented with an error that reads similar to:
{quote}
Aw, shoot. You don't have access with
DuplicateAID@example.com

Looks like you don't have access to this site.
{quote}
* The email address displayed in the error message is not the email address the customer intended to sign in with
 
h3. Notes
* All users on an instance are denied access to JIRA in some cases

h3.Workaround
* -Customers must contact support. The support engineer must escalate to the Identity DoS to fix the problem.-
* We've pushed out a change to the G Suite syncing behaviour that we believe should resolve this issue. The fix requires the administrator of the instance/G Suite account to go to User Management, G Suite, and then disconnect and reconnect their G Suite integration. This should start a sync that should resolve these emails.
If the admin is locked out, Atlassian staff might need to login and disconnect G Suite integration (Customer will need to re-enable it).
fields.summary: G-Suite associated with incorrect Atlassian ID

fields.description:
The sender of emails has recently changed from something like “Recurring Tasks for JIRA (JIRA)” to “addon_com.gebsun.atlassian.rtasks (JIRA)”

This is probably a side-effect of [ACJIRA-1237|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/ACJIRA-1237]
fields.summary: Connect Add-on display name is no longer human readable in emails

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

Currently, it is not possible to have 2 or more different *Full Name* under the same *Atlassian Account*. Due to the reason that the user might have 2 *Cloud Instances*, and will have 1 Support team handling different products.
h3. Suggested Resolution

Provide a feature to allow users to have 2 or more different *Full Name.*
fields.summary: Ability to have different Full name in the same Atlassian Account

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

The new sign on (Atlassian Account) does not display the password field by default, so it is impossible to tab to the password field (as is customary for sign-in forms) after typing the username, without pressing ENTER first.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Show both email and password fields.
fields.summary: Show both email and password fields in login page so that user can use tab (without clicking enter)

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of 7 March 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#4c9aff|bgColor=#deebff}
Hi everyone,

The Atlassian Cloud app in *Azure AD* now supports automated user and group provisioning. If you have Azure AD as your identity provider, you can configure the app to automate the provisioning and deprovisioning process. To get it setup, have a read about [how automatic user provisioning works with Atlassian Cloud|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/user-provisioning-959305316.html] and then follow the instructions on [Azure AD|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/saas-apps/atlassian-cloud-provisioning-tutorial].

As a quick summary:
 * We currently support [*Okta*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/configure-user-provisioning-with-okta-957492956.html], [*OneLogin*|https://onelogin.service-now.com/support?id=kb_article&sys_id=05501489db792708ca1c400e0b9619ea], and [*Azure AD*|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/saas-apps/atlassian-cloud-provisioning-tutorial].
 * For other identity providers, you can use the [User provisioning (SCIM) API (documentation at developer.atlassian.com)|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/admin/user-provisioning/rest/] to sync users and groups over to Atlassian products.

Regards, 
 The Atlassian Access team
{panel}
 
----
*Original request:*

User management REST API in JIRA Cloud do not support user profile updates, this breaks consumer who relay on these API's to update user profiles. 

Fix: Expose public API's (SCIM standard) for user management which allows consumers to provision, update, delete users directly with Atlasssian account
fields.summary: Provide SCIM API's for managing Atlassian account users

fields.description: When using G Suite to manage users, it'd be interesting to have it also syncing the Google group membership to Atlassian product groups.
fields.summary: Ability for G Suite to also sync with the Google group membership

When Cloud instance is connected with G Suite, users would like to hide JIRA login option so that we can force users to login using Google only.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Provide an option to hide/remove JIRA login when it's connected to G Suite
fields.summary: An option to hide JIRA login when it's connected to G Suite

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Customers are constantly receiving unsolicited password reset emails.

When attempting to log in to JIRA/Confluence. Instead of being granted access, the user is presented with this screen:

!password_expired.png|width=665,height=445!

This will happen multiple times while attempting to working on JIRA/Confluence.
h3. Environment
 * Confluence Cloud
 * JIRA Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Login to JIRA/Confluence

h3. Expected Results
 * Logins should work without any error messages or friction.

h3. Actual Results
 * User presented with "Reset your password to continue" message upon login(see screenshot above)

h3. Workaround
 * Set a stronger password as weaker passwords may cause this issue to appear
 * Atlassian Cloud uses an [entropy score|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Password_strength#Entropy_as_a_measure_of_password_strength] to evaluate the strength of people's passwords
fields.summary: Constantly receiving password reset emails and being prompted to reset password

fields.description:
Customers are seeing 404 error pages when trying to log back in right after being logged out from the Administration page.

*Steps to reproduce:*

# Log in to a cloud site
# Click on Application Navigator button on the upper left corner
# Click Configure
# From the Application Navigator page, click Log Out
# On the log in screen, type in credentials

*Expected Result:*
User gets logged in

*Actual Results:*
After a few redirections, site URL gets altered to https://sitename.altassian.net/https://sitename.atlassian.net/plugins/servlet/customize-application-navigator\\ resulting in 404 error

*Additional Info:*
- Same problem occurs while authenticating through OAuth
- Users without any admin privileges won't be able to reproduce as they will not reach the Administration page through the Configure button within the Application Navigator menu. In this case, the button is hidden.

*Workaround:*
Manually change the URL to https://sitename.altassian.net to log in again.
fields.summary: Login redirect URL resulting in 404 error page

fields.description: One of the identity systems is not setting a max-age cookie, this is causing users to be logged out when they close their browser session.
fields.summary: Users logged out of JIRA/Confluence Cloud on browser exit

fields.description:
h1. Summary

Some users of Internet Explorer receive the error message "Something has gone wrong" while trying to sign in to their Atlassian account.
h1. How to reproduce
 # User goes to their Atlassian Cloud site.
 # They are redirected to id.atlassian.com.
 # They enter their email address and password and get redirected to a page with the error message "Something has gone wrong".

h1. Expected Results

Users are signed in and redirected to their Atlassian Cloud site.
h1. Actual Results
 # Users receive the error message "Something has gone wrong".

h1. Solution
As mentioned in [our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/atlassian-cloud-ip-ranges-and-domains-744721662.html#AtlassianCloudIPrangesanddomains-Domainnames], Atlassian Cloud relies on several sites to function. These sites must be allowed in your computer and network's security and privacy settings.

h2. Allow cookies

To use Atlassian Cloud, cookies (first-party and third-party) must be allowed for our sites. In "Internet Options", this can be done either for all sites or just our sites.
h3. Allow cookies for all sites
 # Go to "Internet Options" in the "Control Panel"
 # Go to the "Privacy" tab
 # Under the "Settings" section, click on "Advanced"
 # Adjust your settings as follows:
 !cookies_global.png!

h3. Allow cookies for just Atlassian Cloud sites
 # Go to "Internet Options" in the "Control Panel"
 # Go to the "Privacy" tab
 # Under the "Settings" section, click on "Sites"
 # Allow the following sites to use cookies:
 ** atlassian.com
 ** atlassian.io
 ** atlassian.net
 ** jira.com
!cookies_per_site.png!

h2. Use the correct security level

To use Atlassian Cloud, ensure that you are using the correct security level. In "Internet Options", this can be done either for all sites or just our sites.
h3. Set security level for all sites
 # Go to "Internet Options" in the "Control Panel"
 # Go to the "Security" tab
 # Set the security level for the "Internet" zone to "Medium-high" like so:
 !security_level_global.png!

h3. Set security level for just Atlassian Cloud sites
 # Go to "Internet Options" in the "Control Panel"
 # Go to the "Security" tab
 # Set the security level for the "Trusted sites" zone to "Medium-high" like so:
 !security_level_trusted.png!
 # Next to the "Trusted sites" section, click on the "Sites" button
 # Add the following sites to the "Trusted sites" zone:
 ** https://*.atlassian.com
 ** https://ajax.googleapis.com
 ** https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com
 !security_level_trusted_sites.png!
fields.summary: Users of Internet Explorer receiving the error message "Something has gone wrong"

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Despite having SAML enabled, customers who signup for an account via <CloudURL>/servicedesk/customer/portal will not be redirected to their SAML IDP for authentication.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Enable SAML in your instance
# Navigate to <CloudURL>/servicedesk/customer/portal and signup for a new user (with an email address that is in the claimed domain)
# Attempt to login with this new account

h3. Expected Behavior
The user should be redirected to their SAML IDP for authentication

h3. Observed Behavior
The user are not redirected to their SAML IDP, and instead, are able to login with their newly set Atlassian Account password

h3. Additional Notes
SAML users are not able to signup for an account directly on the portal, as per https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/ID-6289 , but surprisingly, they can signup for an account via ServiceDesk. Though they wont be able to use their SAML auth
fields.summary: ServiceDesk Self Sign up Customers are not using SAML auth even though SAML is enabled
