fields.description:
h3. Summary
Local users are being authenticated against the Atlassian ID on instances where Atlassian Accounts is _not_ enabled.  This causes confusion as the end user is unable to log in to JIRA using their Atlassian Cloud credentials - even though they are instructed to by the login page.  The end user needs to use their Atlassian Account credentials to log in.  JIRA administrators are able to reset account passwords via User Management by specifying a password for a particular account, but this has no effect as authentication is being requested via Atlassian Accounts (AID).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Reset end user password via User Management
# New password does not allow access to applications

h3. Expected Results
* Access granted to applications

h3. Actual Results
* Log in page displays: "Sorry, we didn't recognize that username and password combination. Please double-check and try again."

h3. Notes
* This issue occurs on instances where Atlassian Accounts 
* "hlog" displays the below
{noformat}
[rest.service.resource.HordeTokenResource] User 'user.name' authenticated via their username and not email for basic auth
TP-Processor3 WARN [atlassian.usermanagement.aid.JerseyAtlassianIdClient] Request to AID /verifyCredentials received response with status 403 and error body of AidErrorEntity{errorMessages=[{"errorMessages":["Invalid credentials for user hennie@teleena.com"],"errors":{},"errorCodes":{},"globalErrorCodes":["INVALID_CREDENTIALS"]}], errors={}}
TP-Processor3 ERROR [atlassian.usermanagement.aid.AtlassianIdServiceImpl] Error verifying credentials for user.name@domain.com
java.lang.RuntimeException: AidErrorEntity{errorMessages=[{"errorMessages":["Invalid credentials for user user.name@domain.com"],"errors":{},"errorCodes":{},"globalErrorCodes":["INVALID_CREDENTIALS"]}], errors={}}
{noformat}
* End user's Atlassian account gets eventually gets locked:
{noformat}
java.lang.RuntimeException: AidErrorEntity{errorMessages=[{"errorMessages":["Reached number of invalid password attempts for user user.name@domain.com"],"errors":{},"errorCodes":{},"globalErrorCodes":["REACHED_NUMBER_OF_INVALID_PASSWORD_ATTEMPTS"]}], errors={}}
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
Resetting the account password via [https://id.atlassian.com/login/resetpassword|https://id.atlassian.com/login/resetpassword] and logging in with those credentials will allow access to the JIRA instance.
fields.summary: Atlassian Cloud users are being authenticated against Atlassian ID on instances where Atlassian Account is not enabled

fields.description:
h3.Summary

With SAML enabled, new users are unable to signup for an account to an instance (despite being SAML users from the claimed domain). Existing users that exist before SAML is enabled works fine

h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Enable SAML in your instance
# Enable Public Signup via {{User Management >> Signup Options}}
# Signup with a new user (the user must have the same domain as the claimed domain in {{User Management >> Domains}}
# Wait for the verification email to arrive, then verify

h3.Expected Behavior
New users should have an account created once they verify (after attempts to access the instance), which has access to the instance 

h3.Observed Behavior
The user's account is not created in the instance (although it is created in Atlassian Account), and users will not be able to access the instance
fields.summary: New users can't signup for an account once SAML is enabled

fields.description:
{panel:title=Status Update|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ff7f7f|titleBGColor=#ff7f7f|bgColor=#e5e5e5}

Hi All, In the last couple of days we rolled out a change on the backend that removes a lot of pain associated with this problem. When a site admin clicks resend on the users screen in Site Administration it will first remove them from the bounce list if they were previously added and then try to re-send the email.

Remember to be added to the bounce list in the first place means there was originally a problem with the mailbox we are sending to. This still needs to be resolved first for the mail to be received by the user, i.e mailbox doesn’t exist, mailbox is full, incorrectly setup on the mail server etc. If you hit resend and you have not fixed the local issue, it will become re-blocked when attempting to deliver the mail.

However with this change it should now be much easier and quicker to test and resolve any local issues. Without needing to contact support.

If mail is blocked or re-blocked you will not be notified of it, nor will we notify you if it was removed from the block list. Any successful delivery messages are reports that we were able to deliver to our upstream mail server successfully. Due to the asynchronous nature of how email works this isn’t easily surfaced immediately if that users mailbox has a problem and has bounced. It can take sometime for this to be noticed based on queuing and retries of various mail systems along the way. That said we do have plans to provide this functionality but will take extra time to scope out how we could implement this feature. We wanted to get this fix out first.

{panel}

h3. Summary

For some reason, an invalid email address can find its way in Atlassian Accounts (e.g., the email address does not exist yet because it is being created as part of the same workflow). When the issue for the invalid email address has been fixed, email invitations can no longer be sent from Atlassian Cloud because the email address has already been blocked in the back-end. Furthermore, Atlassian Cloud will show a misleading notification that the email has been sent.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

1. In the User Management page of a cloud instance, create a user using an invalid email (email address not yet created or mailbox is full). Make sure to check *Send invitation email*.
 2. Fix the issue for the email address and make sure it is able to receive emails properly.
 3. Recreate the user or resend the invite in the cloud instance using the same email address.
h3. Expected Results

Atlassian Cloud should specify that the email invitation was not sent or even specify that the email was blocked.
h3. Actual Results

User will be notified that the email has been sent.

!test error.png|thumbnail!
h3. Notes

Although email bounce mainly happens in invite flow, it potentially happens to every type of emails due to receiver's email unavailability.
h3. Workaround

***Updated:* with the latest fix, you're now able to unblock a recipient email that you suspect was blocked via the 'Resend' link in User Management. This will unblock emails automatically before resending

For newly created accounts, please, wait for a few hours before inviting them to your Atlassian Cloud apps, this will allow time for the server to replicate the account.

Please contact Atlassian Support to check if the status of the email address.
fields.summary: Invite emails lost for blocked email addresses

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Recent changes on how users are persisted in the database, both in JIRA and in Confluence, have caused several bugs when importing the files related to users:
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-63788
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-45425
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-64308
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-63746
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-51974

Problems that caused failure in import include:
* Users with duplicate email address (including inactive and in other directories)
* Users with invalid characters in name
* Users whose email address is not considered valid (such as 'user@')

To make things worse, the user import is generally the last step on an import and it only shows a single error, as it ends on the first error it gets. So a 2,3,4... hours import may stop in the very end. No description of how to fix it is given to the user and the user and even after fixing the problem and attempting to import again, another error may happen.

The consequence is that we need to enter a import/fail/fix procedure that may take up to days until all users have are correct.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Run a user checking in the beginning of any JIRA or Confluence import, checking if the users are valid (no email duplication, no invalid characters, only valid emails, etc.). After problems are found, allow users to do changes, including setting new emails for users with duplicate emails, remove invalid characters, change email address if it's not valid, etc.
fields.summary: User verification/change on importing JIRA/Confluence

fields.description:
h2. Summary

Exporting user from User Management page is unable to read Scandinavian (å ä and ö) letters.
h2. Environment

JIRA Cloud 1000.844.1
h2. Steps to reproduce
 # Go to User Management
 # Create a user with Scandinavian in name (e.g: ned håssäan)
 # Export user by clicking on *Export Users*

h2. Expected behavior

The Scandinavian letter is preserved during export
h2. Actual behavior

The Scandinavian letter is not readable and translated to question mark (e.g: ned h?ss?an)
fields.summary: Export user feature fails to translate Scandinavian letters
